item.title: Mamdani Wants to Meet With Major Business Heads, Wylde Says
item.description: New York City mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani will meet with members of New York City’s business community in July, according to one of the city’s most influential power brokers.
item.dc:creator: Nacha Cattan, Laura Nahmias

media:content.media:description: Zohran Mamdani, New York City mayoral candidate, during a mayoral Democratic primary debate in New York, US, on Wednesday, June 4, 2025. The mayoral race has become one of the most crowded in recent memory, with at least nine Democrats with significant fundraising numbers running in this month's primary.

item.title: What Does Supreme Court Ruling on Birthright Citizenship Mean?
item.description: President Donald Trump is fighting to end automatic citizenship for children born to parents who are in the country unlawfully or on temporary visas, part of his broader crackdown on undocumented immigrants and a change that could overturn more than a century of legal precedent.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson

media:content.media:description: Legal and legislative challenges to birthright citizenship have, like Trump’s order, often rested on the argument that the children of undocumented immigrants aren’t “subject to the jurisdiction” of the US.

item.title: Trump Ends Canada Trade Talks in Retaliation Over Digital Tax
item.description: President Donald Trump said he was ending all trade discussions with Canada in retaliation for the country’s digital services tax and threatened to impose a fresh tariff rate within the next week.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner, Mathieu Dion, Melissa Shin

item.title: UVA President Says He Quit Instead of Fighting Against Trump
item.description: University of Virginia President James Ryan said he quit instead of fighting the US government amid a Trump administration probe of the school’s diversity, equity and inclusion efforts.
item.dc:creator: Janet Lorin, Gregory Korte

media:content.media:description: University of Virginia President James Ryan

item.title: Trump Says He’ll Pick a Fed Chair Who Wants to Cut Rates
item.description: President Donald Trump said he would choose a successor for Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell who wants to cut interest rates, a condition that would strike at the heart of the central bank’s independence.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: WASHINGTON, DC - JUNE 27: U.S. President Donald Trump delivers remarks as he meets with Minister of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation of Rwanda Olivier Nduhungirehe and the Foreign Minister of the Democratic Republic of the Congo Thérèse Kayikwamba Wagner in the Oval Office at the White House on June 27, 2025. The meeting took place as a peace agreement brokered by the White House, which hopes to end a conflict in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, was signed by officials of the two African nations. (Photo by Joe Raedle/Getty Images)

item.title: Trump’s Court Win Opens a Path to Clear Hurdles to His Agenda
item.description: The US Supreme Court’s ruling curbing the power of judges to block government actions on a nationwide basis has raised questions about whether dozens of orders that have halted President Donald Trump’s policies will stand.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Tillman

media:content.media:description: The US Supreme Court in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, June 27, 2025. The US Supreme Court let President Donald Trump take steps toward restricting automatic birthright citizenship, though the justices held out the possibility lower courts may again thwart him before the rules can take effect.

item.title: Trump Speeds Up Tax Bill Deadline as Tentative SALT Deal Reached
item.description: President Donald Trump amped up pressure on Congress to speed passage of his tax-cut bill as Republicans reached a tentative deal on the state and local tax deduction, one of the key sticking points in the negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Nacha Cattan, Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: A sculpture of former US President George Washington in the Rotunda of the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, June 2, 2025. Significant changes are in store for President Donald Trump's signature $3.9 trillion tax-cut bill as the Senate begins closed-door talks this week on legislation that squeaked through the House by a single vote.

item.title: Democrats Urge Rubio to Not Fire Diplomats, End Hiring Freeze
item.description: Scores of congressional Democrats are urging Secretary of State Marco Rubio to abandon plans to shrink the State Department workforce, end a hiring freeze and resume offering the Foreign Service Officer Test three times a year.
item.dc:creator: Courtney McBride

media:content.media:description: An exterior view of the US Department of State headquarters in the Foggy Bottom neighborhood in Washington, DC, on April 15, 2025. The US State Department is expected to propose an unprecedented scaling back of Washington's diplomatic reach, multiple news outlets reported Tuesday, shuttering programs and embassies worldwide to slash the budget by almost 50 percent. The proposals, contained in an internal departmental memo said to be under serious discussion by senior officials, would eliminate almost all funding for international organizations such as the United Nations and NATO. (Photo by Jim WATSON / AFP) (Photo by JIM WATSON/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Trump Administration Appeals Harvard Win on Foreign Student Ban
item.description: The government is appealing a court order letting Harvard University continue enrolling foreign students despite President Donald Trump’s proclamation barring their entry to the US.
item.dc:creator: Bob Van Voris

media:content.media:description: Graduating Harvard University students walk through Harvard Square in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

item.title: Trump to Spend Rare DC Weekend Harrying Senate on Tax Bill
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Every Friday, White House correspondent Akayla Gardner delivers a roundup of the key news and events in politics, policy and economics that you need to know. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

item.title: Why Is Trump Deporting Migrants to ‘Third Countries’?
item.description: President Donald Trump’s crackdown on undocumented immigrants has raised concerns about one of his controversial deportation methods: sending noncitizens to countries other than their own — like South Sudan or Libya — with little notice.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson

media:content.media:description: A United States Air Force Boeing C-17 used for deportation flights at Biggs Army Airfield in Fort Bliss, El Paso, Texas, in February. Photographer: Justin Hamel/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Alberta Posts Larger-Than-Projected Surplus, Braces for Deficit
item.description: Alberta posted a larger-than-projected surplus in its most recent fiscal year, providing the oil-rich province with some cushion against an expected trade war-driven shortfall in the current period.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Orland

media:content.media:description: The Walterdale Bridge in Edmonton, Alberta.

item.title: Trump Eyes Cuts to Top Spy Agency as He Downplays Iran Intel
item.description: President Donald Trump is pressing ahead with plans to slash staff at the top US spy agency, determined to act at a time when he’s openly challenged its director and rejected intelligence findings that contradict his public statements.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Drozdiak, Jamie Tarabay, Nancy Cook

media:content.media:description: The Office of the Director of National Intelligence in McLean, Virginia.

item.title: As Hurricane Season Picks Up, Key Forecasting Tool Access Set to End
item.description: The US Navy will no longer distribute certain satellite readings, a move that will leave forecasters without important insights into storms’ strength and structure.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Rosenthal, Brian K Sullivan

media:content.media:description: A satellite image shows Hurricane Helene in the Gulf of Mexico moving towards Florida, on Sept. 26 2024.

item.title: Congo, Rwanda Sign US-Backed Peace Deal to End Decades of War
item.description: The Democratic Republic of Congo and Rwanda agreed to a US-backed peace deal meant to end years of deadly conflict and promote development in Congo’s volatile eastern region.
item.dc:creator: Michael J Kavanagh

media:content.media:description: Rwanda’s Nduhungirehe, from left, Rubio and Democratic Republic of the Congo’s Kayikwamba during a signing ceremony at the State Department

item.title: Colombia Holds Key Rate at 9.25% After Two Credit Downgrades
item.description: Colombia’s central bank resisted government pressure to slash interest rates a day after the nation’s deteriorating fiscal outlook triggered two ratings downgrades.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Medina

media:content.media:description: Traffic in Bogota, Colombia, on Friday, Dec. 20, 2024. Colombia’s central bank unexpectedly slowed its monetary easing campaign as fiscal concerns are weakening the nation’s currency and adding to inflation risks.

item.title: California Democrats Push Reform to Stop Refinery Shutdowns
item.description: A group of California Democrats is looking to ease the state’s gasoline standards and streamline permitting for refineries in a bid to prevent more fuelmakers from shutting down and raising costs for the state’s drivers.
item.dc:creator: Nathan Risser

media:content.media:description: A refinery in Wilmington, California.

item.title: Trump Says He Dropped Plans to Ease Iran Sanctions, Slams Leader
item.description: US President Donald Trump said he considered easing sanctions on Iran after a ceasefire but would instead keep economic penalties on the country in place, lashing out at Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei for claiming victory in the war with Israel.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump during a news conference at the White House in Washington, DC, on June 27.

item.title: Cuba’s Volleyball Team Barred From US Event in Latest Sport Spat
item.description: Cuba’s volleyball team was denied visas for a tournament in Puerto Rico, the latest example of a US travel crackdown that the communist government blasted as discriminatory and said could hurt its ability to participate in the Olympics.
item.dc:creator: Jim Wyss

media:content.media:description: Members of the Cuban volleyball team compete against team Brazil during the 2023 Pan Am Games in Santiago, Chile.

item.title: Trump Stresses July Tariff Threat, Bessent Teases Extension
item.description: President Donald Trump hardened his threat to raise tariffs on certain countries by his July 9 deadline, while Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent signaled there may be some extensions to wrap up major pacts by the Labor Day holiday.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai, Daniel Flatley

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent

item.title: South Africa Presses US on G-20 Absence as Leaders Summit Looms
item.description: South Africa will ask the US government to confirm its future participation in Group of 20 engagements, after American officials failed to attend a preparatory meeting this week.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, right, and Cyril Ramaphosa, South Africa's president, during a meeting in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, May 21, 2025. Trump rejected Ramaphosa's argument that there’s no genocide against White Afrikaners, airing a video and showing images in the Oval Office that he said showed how they were beaten and killed.

item.title: Wall Street Democrats Sweat as DNC Chair Navigates Mamdani Surge
item.description: The mood was uneasy as Democratic donors gathered at a Midtown steakhouse for lunch. The night before, progressive candidate Zohran Mamdani had all but clinched the party’s nomination for New York mayor — triggering fears by moderates that national Democrats might veer toward socialism.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Korte, Todd Gillespie, Sridhar Natarajan

media:content.media:description: Zohran Mamdani, New York City mayoral candidate, during an election event.

item.title: Supreme Court Curbs Judges in Birthright Case as Trump Touts Win
item.description: A sharply divided US Supreme Court limited the power of judges to block government policies nationwide but left unresolved a fight over President Donald Trump’s restrictions on automatic birthright citizenship.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: A pedestrian holding a baby outside the US Supreme Court in Washington, D.C., US, on Wednesday, May 11, 2022. Senate Democrats were blocked in their attempt to enshrine abortion rights in federal law in a vote that highlighted both the deep divide on the politically explosive issue and the party's schism over ending the filibuster to achieve their goals. Photographer: Sarah Silbiger/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Says July 4 Tax-Cut Bill Deadline Isn’t the ‘End All’ Date
item.description: President Donald Trump said that his self-imposed July 4 goal to pass his tax bill isn’t an absolute deadline, remarks that give Republican negotiators additional breathing room as lawmakers remain at loggerheads over several issues in the massive economic package.
item.dc:creator: Cam Kettles, Erik Wasson, Alicia Diaz, Maeve Sheehey

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent

item.title: Putin Says Russia to Seek Defense Cuts; How Much Depends on War
item.description: President Vladimir Putin said Russia plans to cut defense spending, acknowledging growing strains on the budget even as he insisted that reductions would depend on winning his war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Halpin

media:content.media:description: Russian T-90M tanks drive through central Moscow during a rehearsal for the Victory Day parade, on May 3.

item.title: Canada’s Digital Services Tax Stays in Place Despite G-7 Deal
item.description: Canada is proceeding with its digital services tax on technology companies such as Meta Platforms Inc. despite a Group of Seven agreement that resulted in removing the Section 899 “revenge tax” proposal from US President Donald Trump’s tax bill.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Shin

media:content.media:description: Parliament Hill in Ottawa.

item.title: Keralty Blasts Petro After Top Colombia Court Sides With Insurer
item.description: Health group Keralty SAS said it will press ahead with legal action against the Colombian government after a top court overturned the takeover of its insurer in the South American nation.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Jaramillo

media:content.media:description: An EPS Sanitas medical center in Bogota, Colombia. Photographer: Nathalia Angarita/Bloomberg

item.title: Supreme Court Bolsters Religious Rights in LGBTQ Book Case
item.description: The US Supreme Court said public school parents have a right to opt out of classroom lessons that intrude on their religious beliefs, ruling that a Maryland county probably violated the Constitution by using LGBTQ-friendly books without notice to parents.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr, Erik Larson

media:content.media:description: Supporters advocating for religious rights demonstrate outside the US Supreme Court Building in Washington, DC, on April 22.

item.title: Albania Takes Stake in Jared Kushner’s $1.4 Billion Tourism Plan
item.description: Albania established a state-owned company to take a stake in a $1.4 billion luxury resort project led by Jared Kushner, Donald Trump’s son-in-law.
item.dc:creator: Gresa Kraja

media:content.media:description: Tourists visit the St. Mary's Monastery on Zvrnec island in Vlora, Albania.

item.title: Romanian Leader Pledges More Budget Measures to Curb Deficit
item.description: Romania’s premier outlined fresh measures to cut the ballooning budget deficit as the new government seeks to safeguard the country’s investment-grade rating and ease investor concern.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: Designated Prime Minister Ilie Bolojan gives a joint press statement with the Romanian President at Cotroceni Palace, the Romanian Presidency's headquarters, in Bucharest June 20, 2025.
